issue.title: pytorch NFSP doesn't match tensorflow NFSP
issue.body:
I ran [examples/leduc_nfsp.py](https://github.com/deepmind/open_spiel/blob/master/open_spiel/python/examples/leduc_nfsp.py) with the given tensorflow NFSP, and I also ran it with the pytorch NFSP. For both runs, I used the same command-line arguments (I used hyperparameters from [Walton & Lisy, 2021](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2103.00187.pdf). The Tensorflow run seems to work well, matching the results in the aforementioned paper. The pytorch run does drastically worse.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1139798/216159102-f709d0ff-e58f-49c6-b32d-bc6b4a4c194c.png)

Filing this issue here for someone to look into this. I may or may not look into it myself soon.

comment.body:
> ok, thank you for your reply. I will try to find the difference.

Any luck? If not, I think we should remove this soon. Then we could list fixing it in the call for contributions.

issue.title: flag.h do not include
issue.body:
Greetings, I'm relatively new to programming, so please bear with me if my question appears to be basic. I'm attempting to create a WebAssembly (WASM) using C++ and Python  game code. My aim is to run two game examples in WASM and create a template for this purpose.

However, I'm encountering an issue. As can be seen on the referenced page, I'm unable to run the C++ game example (open_spiel/examples/example.cc). It seems like the path to flag.h is not working, and I'm not sure how to fix this.

My open_spiel flag.h tree path.
open_spiel/
--open_spiel/
----abseil-cpp/
------absiel/
--------flags/flag.h

How you can see, the archive flag.h exists, but on the open_spiel/examples/example.cc the compiler signals the error open_spiel/abseil-cpp/absl/flags/flag.h: No such file or directory gcc

Im using VsCode IDE and i installed all depedencies of documentation (Clang++, python3, virtual-env etc)

comment.body:
> I'm using Ubuntu 22.04

Whoops, I saw VsCode and mad some incorrect assumptions. Glad it all worked out for you in the end!

comment.body:
> It would be a workaround trying to compile only that file. Did you follow all instructions for installation? When you execute open_spiel/scripts/build_and_run_tests.sh all code will be compiled and you should see tests passing. Then under the <project_root>/build folder inside the examples folder you can start the programm you wish in your case ./example . Im not sure if the error just happens if you already followed the steps because it wasnt clear out of your post.

Finally, I managed to run the tests! Thank you, I was able to compile all the C++ examples and generate their executables. I am familiarizing myself with the framework and didn't realize my approach was a "workaround".

issue.title: Add formatting pre-commit hooks
issue.body:
From what I can tell the repo does not have consistent formatting on the c++ side nor on the Python side due to there not being a shared formatting setup in the repo (unsure about Julia/Rust). 
Yet, this could be as easy as setting up a .clang-format and black config and pre-commit hooks! The pre-commits may also be extended for automatic linting (flake8, mypy) and more.

Advantages:
- standardized code!
- no need for manual linting, formatting, or other requests from PR contributors as every commit is automatically checked and corrected (if e.g. just formatting)
- clear formatting guidelines for every contributor and no accidental large diffs in PRs (had this problem myself)
- no extra dependency on the user side 

Disadvantages:
- a one-off behemoth diff that formats the entire codebase
- **developers** will need to install the `pre-commit` package and run `pre-commit install` once inside the repo (could also be automated in the install script)

If this is interesting for the project, then I would suggest starting with formatters in the pre-commit and adding linters later. I could provide a PR to try this.
What do you think?

issue.title: TensorArray Not Used on line 91 of rl_losses_test.py
issue.body:
Hello!

I found an AI-Specific Code smell in your project.
The smell is called: TensorArray Not Used

You can find more information about it in this paper: https://dl.acm.org/doi/abs/10.1145/3522664.3528620.

According to the paper, the smell is described as follows:

| **Problem**  | If the developer initializes an array using tf.constant() and tries to assign a new value to it in the loop to keep it growing, the code will run into an error. The developer can fix this error by the low-level tf.while\_loop() API. However, it is inefficient coding in this way. A lot of intermediate tensors are built in this process. |
| ------------- | :------------- |
| **Solution**  | **Using tf.TensorArray() for growing array in the loop is a better solution for this kind of problem in TensorFlow 2.**  |
| **Impact** | **Efficiency, Error-proneness**  |

Example:
 ```diff
### TensorFlow
import tensorflow as tf
@tf.function
def fibonacci(n):
    a = tf.constant(1)
    b = tf.constant(1)
-    c = tf.constant([1, 1])
+    c = tf.TensorArray(tf.int32, n)
+    c = c.write(0, a)
+    c = c.write(1, b)

    for i in range(2, n):
        a, b = b, a + b
-       c = tf.concat([c, [b]], 0)
+		c = c.write(i, b)

-    return c
+	 return c.stack()

  ```
You can find the code related to this smell in this link: https://github.com/deepmind/open_spiel/blob/b18a597a795c202d8c843020eed1ecc9d1de1422/open_spiel/python/algorithms/losses/rl_losses_test.py#L81-L101.

I also found instances of this smell in other files, such as:

.

I hope this information is helpful!

issue.title: Pre-commit setup for the repo
issue.body:
This PR addresses what has been mentioned in #1070.

What this PR includes:
- pre-commit configuration for **_formatters_**:
   - **clang-forma**t: 
   c++ project files formatting
   - **pyink**: 
   google's python formatter that is close to black, but allows 2-indent formatting (oh the humanity...)
   - **cmake-format**:
  formatting style for cmake files
   - **isort**: 
  sort python imports alphabetically (can use profile=black, so I hope this profile works with pyink too)
   - **black**: 
  the python formatter (commented out but added for when google policy on 2-indent changes)
- **pylint**:
using google's official configuration. Since this config enforces 2-indent, **pyink** is needed.
- common pre-commit **_checks_**:
   - id: check-added-large-files
   - id: check-case-conflict
   - id: check-docstring-first (currently uncommented as some files would need manual changing)
   - id: check-merge-conflict
   - id: check-symlinks
   - id: check-toml
   - id: check-yaml
   - id: debug-statements
   - id: end-of-file-fixer
   - id: mixed-line-ending
   - id: requirements-txt-fixer
   - id: trailing-whitespace
- common **_python checks_**:
   - python-check-blanket-noqa
   - id: python-check-blanket-type-ignore
   - id: python-no-log-warn (uncommented because clashes in multiple places where logging.warn has been used)
   - id: python-no-eval
   - id: python-use-type-annotations 

As a side effect of the pre-commit checks I have moved the setup definition into a `pyproject.toml`, since it allows to also write the configurations for some of these tools. In consequence:
- _`pyproject.toml` now holds the metadata of the project (version, authors, license, etc.)_
- _`setup.py` is only the extension builder_

The dev-tools needed to run these pre-commits have also been added to the the `pyproject.toml` as optional dependencies of the dev group and could then be installed via:
```
pip install 'open_spiel[dev]'
```
or locally 
```
pip install '.[dev]'
```

If this PR is accepted a remark in the docs should be made for developers who wish to contribute the upstream to run `pre-commit install` on their repo in order to activate the hooks.

pull_request.title: Refactor using string_view and fix undefined behaviour
pull_request.body:
This PR achieves the following things:

### Refactor: `const std::string&` --> `std::string_view` wherever possible and sensible. 

This was done for performance reasons: `const std::string&` automatically converts `const char*` and `std::string` r-values resulting in unnecessary heap allocations. A `string_view` avoids any allocations at the risk of dangling references which is not a problem if common rules are followed: generally only use in function parameters, never return `string_view`, never store `string_view`.
This point alone touches many files of the repo and creates a large diff (sorry).

### Feature: Allow Heterogenous Lookup (HL) in maps using `std::string` as key.

One of the features added by this PR is HL: looking up the value of a st::map/unordered_map associated with a key of type `std::string` via key-simile types `const char*` and `std::string_view`. HL is crucial in ensuring the performance of e.g. `map.find(str)` lookups to not be dominated by the forced conversion to `std::string` (heap allocations). It works by supplying a custom Comparator (ordered maps) or custom Hash and Equality (unordered maps) types for the map templates which allow to compare/hash/eq-check objects within the string family (currently defined as `string, string_view, const char*`) and forego the need to convert every lookup to `std::string`. Two points of interest:
- HL requires a little template metaprogramming machinery to filter out unaccepted types (SFINAE and static asserts). This  is provided in the new files `utils/heterogenous_lookup.h` and `utils/type_traits.h`.
- C++17 does not support HL. Abseil containers however do and since this repo relies on abseil machinery in many parts I have gone ahead and used the drop-in container replacements of abseil for the std counterparts. This may lead to changes in the expected performance of some core parts in the repo (whether for the better or worse I dare not say, abseil claims their containers are better).

### Bugfix: Fix undefined behaviour in `GameParameter`

So far, the class `GameParameter` has held a member of type `std::map< std::string, GameParameter>` which represents the usage of an incomplete type as the value type of a map template. According to my understanding, incomplete value types are not defined behaviour in this context in c++17 (and AFAIK still unchanged in later standards). Only smart pointers and some specific containers are allowed to hold incomplete value types (e.g. `vector`/`list`). Therefore, I refactored the member as a mapping of `std::shared_ptr<GameParameter>` and moved it to an abseil container to also enable HL. This has consequences to nearly the entire repo. For example, the tests construct parameter objects via `GameParameter(args...)` which up until now provided values. These calls are now replaced everywhere by `MakeGameParameter(args...)` which automatically returns a shared ptr of type `GameParameter`. Other places now needed to deref these pointers (`->` instead `.`), comparison of two objects of type `GameParameters` (heed the plural, it is meant) is no longer meaningfully provided by the default comparison of keys and values in a map due to the values being shared pointers; a custom equality function is needed. Many other small changes were necessary. While doing so, I also refactored some of the functions around `GameParameter`. When in Rome...

### Minor refactors of unnecessary copies 

E.g. pass-by-value instances of `std::shared_ptr` and other points in which copies were created without need.

Overall this PR touches a vast amount of the c++ codebase, so apologies for the massive diff.

pull_request.title: Add pre-commit verification to CI
pull_request.body:
Builds on #1071.

Adds a CI step that verifies all pre-commit checks pass, otherwise fails the build step and exits. Not built on #1071 yet to keep diff small and the changes easily in sight. Will need #1071 merged into it to become operational.

Currently set as a condition for the build job to run, but can be set as a side job.

Merging this PR will mean that the entire codebase needs to apply the checks and formatting mandated by the pre-commit setup and as such requires one behemoth PR to apply these changes, otherwise all CI steps will constantly fail.

**_I do not recommend merging this until all open PRs in consideration for the project have been merged or closed so that the entire repo can see all of the pre-commit hooks applied to it._**

this is a pull request draft, not a final version

Add Pytorch GPU support for Pytorch DQN and NFSP.

This PR essentially follows the approach outlined in #538. This PR does not make the corresponding changes for the tensorflow versions of these algorithms (related: #177)

issue.body:

However, I'm encountering an issue. As can be seen on the referenced page, I'm unable to run the C++ game example (open_spiel/examples/example.cc). It seems like the path to flag.h is not working, and I'm not sure how to fix this.

My open_spiel flag.h tree path.
open_spiel/
--open_spiel/
----abseil-cpp/
------absiel/
--------flags/flag.h

How you can see, the archive flag.h exists, but on the open_spiel/examples/example.cc the compiler signals the error open_spiel/abseil-cpp/absl/flags/flag.h: No such file or directory gcc

Im using VsCode IDE and i installed all depedencies of documentation (Clang++, python3, virtual-env etc)
